Green, green, green are the in..oining- freshmen but still greener
re some sophomores. Last year's
;ophomor'e class evidently did not
o its work well, for last Monday
orne of the green sophs stopped a
Phi Beta Kappa graduate student,
and wanted to know "where's
your button?"
These self-appointed guardians
of school spirit started in on the
frosh early last Monday morning,
and the frosh, dazed and bewildered, calmly took what was offered. The next day, however,
few hardy souls persisted in
wearing hats and keeping hands
in pockets. Such behavior hurt
lie delicate feelings of the sophs,

Dr. Norman F. Eberman, associate professor of Chemistry at
Hopkins, who had been missing for
two days, was found dead Tuesday
night, sitting upright in a chair in
the summer. home of his father-inlaw, W. S. Summers, at Pines-onSevern.
The summer home of Mr. Summers had been closed for several
weeks and neighbors became anxious on discovering a light shining
within. Police Justice John \V.
Anderson, of Annapolis, was notified and he and Dr. Joseph Joyce
went to the house to investigate,
finding Dr. Eberrnan there.
Dead Twelse Hours

Dr. Joyce, after a hasty examination, stated that Dr. Eberman
had been dead between twelve and
twenty-four hours and also, that
death was probably due to poison.
As there was no trace of
found in the cottage Dr. J,
pressed the belief that it h
ably been swallowed outsio,
bungalow.
According to reports, Dr.
man left his home in Baltimol
Sunday afternoon expectii
make final preparations f(
opening of college on the folk ,,ing
day. When he did not return at
the usual time his wife notified Hopkins authorities. A thorough search
of the buildings and grounds was
made without obtaining any clue to
his whereabouts, and his disappearance was then reported to the
Police.
Hopkins in 1921

Dr. Eberman, a native of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, was graduated from Franklin and Marshall
College in 1919. After receiving
his master of science degree from
the University of Maine in 1921 he
entered the graduate department at
Hopkins and was awarded the degree df doctor of philosophy two
years later, joining the faculty in
the same year.
For the present time, at least,
there will be no one appointed to
take the place of Dr. Eberman. His
courses will be taken over by other
members of the Chemistry Department.

The tardiness of several
colleges in sending official
scores to the National Lacrosse Association has resulted in the failure of that body
to announce the championship
team of the past season, Mr.
Casper Wylie said today. He
added that the decision will be
reached before October 15.
The concensus of opinion
is that the championship will
be awarded to Johns Hopkins
or Syracuse. The showing of
the Blue jays against OxfordCambridge and the Onondaga
Indians has installed them as
favorites.

not observed to the fullest extent that honesty and truthfulness which
one gentleman expects of another, the whole system is shaken.
Bertuch and Bolton
This code of a gentleman as it has developed at Hopkins is known
as the Honor System. Its demands upon the individual are few, but
those few are as strict as the advantages of the system are broad. To
see to it that your actions and your relations with your fellows are free
from any taint of dishonesty or unfairness sums up the working rule
of the Honor System. A simple rule, but one that must be observed to
the letter.

Any divergence from it is the one offense which no true

Hopkins man will ever pardon.
The Honor System is the most prized of Hopkins' traditions, and
it is the most fragile, for the attitude of a few individuals could wreck
it beyond repaiir. Yet for years it has survived. This is all the more
remarkable since each year its success or failure is entrusted to an
incoming freshman class, unfamiliar with the spirit or the operation of
the code.

It is a great responsibility, but so far no freshman class

has ever failed.

The Pilot's Letter
Forest Park, Ill.
June 16, 1926
The Parker Pen Company,
Gentlemen:
At 4:10 P.M. yesterday I took off in
my Yackey plane from Checkerboard
field. When I reached an altitude of
3000 feet I leaned over the side and
dropped a Parker Over-size Duofold
Pen. A few minutes later I made a
landing near my starting point, and a
crowd was examining the same Parker
Duofold pen, which had landed on
hard ground. To my great surprise,
the pen had not been damaged in the
slightest by its 3000 feet drop.

Signed with the Parker that
dropped 3000feet.

break—

Discuss Second Day

During the morning of the
/second day discussions were
/ conducted at the Assembly
Hour by Bull, Schaal, and Ensor.
They treated several important
phases of the Y. M. C. A."s work
on the Campus. The rest of the
day was taken up with group
meetings, an open period, and recreation in the afternoon. The
upperclassmen won closely contested baseball and volley ball
• games from the freshmen. Bull
and Rawlins took first honors in
the horseshoe tournament. "Ted'
Fischer created great excitement
when he caught himself on-a nail
in sliding into the water.
Leber Speaks

The second evening "Charlie"
Leber spoke on the "Golden
Rule." The freshmen who proceeded to stage a pajama parade
were mistaken for bootleggers
and chased. One man broke his
ankle in the scramble. At bedtime the campers were regaled
by one of the upperclassmen
who had lost his pajamas. That
same evening several men established a record by sleeping
through an entire moving picture
show.
On Sunday
morning Dr.
Swartz delivered an inspiring address, the title of which was
"Christianity and Its Application."
Men nominated to the freshman
Y. M. C. A. cabinet at the retreat
were: Deats, president; Mayhew,
vice-president; Beeuwkes, secretary; and Markle,- treasurer.

He's Still
Telling the Judges
"The speaker for
t h e affirmative,
ladies and gentlemen, will be Mr.
C. M. Laffoon."
That line was not
unfamiliar to student groups at the
C. Al. Latoun
Cniversity of Missouri a few years ago.
Now the undergraduate debater
of other days is the Design Engineer in the Turbo-Generator Section of the Power Engineering
Department. He is in his eleventh
year at the Westinghouse Company.
Laffoon today is the builder of
the fastest things that go, electrically. For those intricate high-speed
machines, he must not only act as
designer, but must often assist in
selling, and must look after the
service when problems arise in
operation. Because the designer is
the man who knows; he is the
"speaker for the affirmative."
"Honorable judges" are fact-seeking engineers of electric light and
power companies.

7'he question sometimes is asked:
Where do young men get when
they e'nte'r a large industrial organization? Have they opportunity to
,-xercise creative talents? Or are
they forced into narrow grooves?
This series of advertisements
throws light on these questions. Each
advertisement takes up the record of
a college man who came with the
Westinghouse Company within recent
years after graduationfrom his uni-

q

f'ersity.

Out of a clear sky one day Westinghouse called for a high-speed
generator for use in commercial
transmission of radio messages.
There was no such machine. Laffoon designed one. Then, through
an unexpected change in a trade
situation, the machine was not
used. Did it go to the scrap heap?
Read and see.
Industry had been seeking a
better way to melt expensive metal
of high heat resistance—aluminum,
platinum, certain alloy steels, and
the like. Ordinary smelting methods couldn't be used. Properties

had to be kept unchanged; and the
great heat liquefied the ordinary
crucible as well as- the metal. Laffoon's discarded radio- generator
was .found to offer an ideal application to a new high- frequency
induction furnace for melting those
special metals; and so Laffoon designed that machine.
. You can measure the advance
in high-speed -turbo-generator apparatus by comparing the models
of 1918 (when Laffoon entered the
particular field to which he has
contributed), with those of 1926.
Then 25,000 KVA was some machine. Now, at 62,000 KVA, no
limit is set on the future.
High-speed machines must be
fitted to the individual needs of
customers. A ft er understanding
what the customer wants, the design engineer must determine the
size, weight, dimensions and performance, depending on voltage,
frequency and speed of the installation. Then he must "follow
through."
Men who "follow through" in
any phase of electrical engineering
may have confidence in their careers at Westinghouse.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 1, 1926
FROSH FORCED TO DANCE
CHARLESTON

DRAMA OF FIVE COUNTRIES
IS REPRESENTED ON
PLAYSHOP LIST

(Continued from Page I Col. 2)

Two Performances Will Be Devoted to
Original Plays by Hopkins
Authors

This season's program of the
Homewood Playshop is heralded as
the most afribitious in the history
of the organization. The plays to
be presented in 1926-27 comprise a
study of the drama of five countries: Norway, Russia, Spain, Germany, and China.
A characteristic full length play,
or three one-act plays, will ,be presented for the literature of each
country. On the Friday evening
preceding the first performance of
each play a competent authority
will give a lecture .on the drama of
the country concerned.
The Playshop was first organized
in December 1921 as one of a class
of dramatic societies known all over
the -.country-- as -the-Little- Theaters,
whose object in general is to foster the study of the drama for the
sake of instruction as well as entertainment.
During the coming season, it is
announced, special attention will be
given to original plays and authors
are asked to submit their work early in the year. Two performances
made up entirely of these plays are
contemplated.
The Board of Governors of the
Playshop is as follows: John. Earle
Uhler, instructor in English; Dr.
John C. French, Collegiate Professor of English; Dr. H. Carrington
Lancaster, Professor of French Literature; Dr. Kemp lalone, Professor of English Philology; Mrs.
Broadus Mitchell, Mrs. C. A. Nelson, and Miss Alta E. Thompson.
instructor in College for Teachers.
The first lecture of the Playshop's
program will be on the drama of
Norway, to be given November 5.
This will be followed by the presentation of a Norwegian play on November 11, 12, and 13.

night, sitting upright in a chair in
the summer. home of his father-inlaw, W. S. Summers, at Pines-onSevern.
The summer home of Mr. Summers had been closed for several
weeks and neighbors became anxious on discovering a light shining
within. Police Justice John \V.
Anderson, of Annapolis, was notified and he and Dr. Joseph Joyce
went to the house to investigate,
finding Dr. Eberrnan there.
Dead Twelse Hours

twenty-four hours and also, that
death was probably due to poison.

made without obtaining any clue to
his whereabouts, and his disappearance was then reported to the

Bertuch and Bolton
This code of a gentleman as it has developed at Hopkins is known
as the Honor System. Its demands upon the individual are few, but
those few are as strict as the advantages of the system are broad. To
see to it that your actions and your relations with your fellows are free
from any taint of dishonesty or unfairness sums up the working rule
of the Honor System. A simple rule, but one that must be observed to
the letter.

Any divergence from it is the one offense which no true

Hopkins man will ever pardon.
The Honor System is the most prized of Hopkins' traditions, and
it is the most fragile, for the attitude of a few individuals could wreck
it beyond repaiir. Yet for years it has survived. This is all the more
remarkable since each year its success or failure is entrusted to an
incoming freshman class, unfamiliar with the spirit or the operation of
the code.

It is a great responsibility, but so far no freshman class

has ever failed.

The Parker Pen Company,
Gentlemen:
At 4:10 P.M. yesterday I took off in
my Yackey plane from Checkerboard
field. When I reached an altitude of
3000 feet I leaned over the side and
dropped a Parker Over-size Duofold
Pen. A few minutes later I made a
landing near my starting point, and a
crowd was examining the same Parker
Duofold pen, which had landed on
hard ground. To my great surprise,
the pen had not been damaged in the
slightest by its 3000 feet drop.

He's Still
Telling the Judges
"The speaker for
t h e affirmative,
ladies and gentlemen, will be Mr.
C. M. Laffoon."
That line was not
unfamiliar to student groups at the
C. Al. Latoun
Cniversity of Missouri a few years ago.
Now the undergraduate debater
of other days is the Design Engineer in the Turbo-Generator Section of the Power Engineering
Department. He is in his eleventh
year at the Westinghouse Company.
Laffoon today is the builder of
the fastest things that go, electrically. For those intricate high-speed
machines, he must not only act as
designer, but must often assist in
selling, and must look after the
service when problems arise in
operation. Because the designer is
the man who knows; he is the
"speaker for the affirmative."
"Honorable judges" are fact-seeking engineers of electric light and
power companies.

7'he question sometimes is asked:
Where do young men get when
they e'nte'r a large industrial organization? Have they opportunity to
,-xercise creative talents? Or are
they forced into narrow grooves?
This series of advertisements
throws light on these questions. Each
advertisement takes up the record of
a college man who came with the
Westinghouse Company within recent
years after graduationfrom his uni-

q

f'ersity.

Out of a clear sky one day Westinghouse called for a high-speed
generator for use in commercial
transmission of radio messages.
There was no such machine. Laffoon designed one. Then, through
an unexpected change in a trade
situation, the machine was not
used. Did it go to the scrap heap?
Read and see.
Industry had been seeking a
better way to melt expensive metal
of high heat resistance—aluminum,
platinum, certain alloy steels, and
the like. Ordinary smelting methods couldn't be used. Properties

had to be kept unchanged; and the
great heat liquefied the ordinary
crucible as well as- the metal. Laffoon's discarded radio- generator
was .found to offer an ideal application to a new high- frequency
induction furnace for melting those
special metals; and so Laffoon designed that machine.
. You can measure the advance
in high-speed -turbo-generator apparatus by comparing the models
of 1918 (when Laffoon entered the
particular field to which he has
contributed), with those of 1926.
Then 25,000 KVA was some machine. Now, at 62,000 KVA, no
limit is set on the future.
High-speed machines must be
fitted to the individual needs of
customers. A ft er understanding
what the customer wants, the design engineer must determine the
size, weight, dimensions and performance, depending on voltage,
frequency and speed of the installation. Then he must "follow
through."
Men who "follow through" in
any phase of electrical engineering
may have confidence in their careers at Westinghouse.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 1, 1926
FROSH FORCED TO DANCE
CHARLESTON

DRAMA OF FIVE COUNTRIES
IS REPRESENTED ON
PLAYSHOP LIST

(Continued from Page I Col. 2)

Two Performances Will Be Devoted to
Original Plays by Hopkins
Authors

This season's program of the
Homewood Playshop is heralded as
the most afribitious in the history
of the organization. The plays to
be presented in 1926-27 comprise a
study of the drama of five countries: Norway, Russia, Spain, Germany, and China.
A characteristic full length play,
or three one-act plays, will ,be presented for the literature of each
country. On the Friday evening
preceding the first performance of
each play a competent authority
will give a lecture .on the drama of
the country concerned.
The Playshop was first organized
in December 1921 as one of a class
of dramatic societies known all over
the -.country-- as -the-Little- Theaters,
whose object in general is to foster the study of the drama for the
sake of instruction as well as entertainment.
During the coming season, it is
announced, special attention will be
given to original plays and authors
are asked to submit their work early in the year. Two performances
made up entirely of these plays are
contemplated.
The Board of Governors of the
Playshop is as follows: John. Earle
Uhler, instructor in English; Dr.
John C. French, Collegiate Professor of English; Dr. H. Carrington
Lancaster, Professor of French Literature; Dr. Kemp lalone, Professor of English Philology; Mrs.
Broadus Mitchell, Mrs. C. A. Nelson, and Miss Alta E. Thompson.
instructor in College for Teachers.
The first lecture of the Playshop's
program will be on the drama of
Norway, to be given November 5.
This will be followed by the presentation of a Norwegian play on November 11, 12, and 13.

Dr. M. L. Raney, librarian
of the Johns Hopkins library, will announce, in tile

of Chicago.

that university is coming to

whether he will accept the
new position at the midwestern college.. ,

Centre College in Kentucky,

elevated to the post of librarian which he holds. at the
